FAMILY MEMBER: When his urine-
DOCTOR: Mm Hmm.

DOCTOR: Okay.

DOCTOR: Yeah.

DOCTOR: Okay good.

DOCTOR: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay. The CAT scan also looks good. Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. That’s good. That’s pleasing isn’t it J___.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
PATIENT: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: We’re frustrated.
DOCTOR: But he’s doing okay?
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: He’s having some back pain.
DOCTOR: Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: We’re just kind of…
DOCTOR: Show me where.
DOCTOR: paper shuffling
DOCTOR: Because the bone scan is not up yet.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did.
PATIENT: xxx
FAMILY MEMBER: We just did it though.
DOCTOR: Right here? Yeah I know that’s why it’s not. Does this hurt when I push?
PATIENT: Not – a little bit.
DOCTOR: A little bit. Not too bad though.
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: Is there anything that brings on the pain?
FAMILY MEMBER: Let me tell you, I think sometimes J___ over exerts himself.
PATIENT: I might if I have…
FAMILY MEMBER: And he’s not walking this time. He has an unsteady gait. He’s stumbling.
DOCTOR: No? Really?
PATIENT: No I ain’t walking the same.
FAMILY MEMBER: And I told him he’s a fall risk so I’d like him to take his cane with him. He says well it’s in my truck, but you can fall going from the house to your truck.
DOCTOR: I agree. Better to keep it.
FAMILY MEMBER: Period.
DOCTOR: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s…

FAMILY MEMBER: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures
FAMILY MEMBER: xxx
DOCTOR: A fracture now would really set us back. So-
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes because we have brittle bones.

DOCTOR: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often.
FAMILY MEMBER: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: -and keep him from harm.
DOCTOR: Yep.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because we’re doing
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: a little bit better
DOCTOR: Mm Hmm.
FAMILY MEMBER: with the diet but this is the thing. I found out at night when he’s not sleeping, he’s watching TV and eating.
DOCTOR: laughs
FAMILY MEMBER: But I want him to eat the right things. I buy more fruits
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: and stuff
DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: but sometimes he gets snacks he shouldn’t have.
DOCTOR: Yep.
FAMILY MEMBER: But there’s not Metformin so we don’t have anything to combat all these sweets. So we need
DOCTOR: Was he not taking Metformin at all?
FAMILY MEMBER: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function,
DOCTOR: Oh okay because of that.
FAMILY MEMBER: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor
DOCTOR: Mm Hmm.
FAMILY MEMBER: before all this treatment even started.
DOCTOR: Really?
FAMILY MEMBER: She was like…
DOCTOR: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication.
FAMILY MEMBER: I think that’s a good idea.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies.
PATIENT: Oh, oh…
FAMILY MEMBER: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then.
DOCTOR: Okay. Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse.
DOCTOR: This is much better than
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah
DOCTOR: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah
DOCTOR: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas…
DOCTOR: The treatment is working and things are looking up.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s why we’re so glad to be here but you’ve got some people that were mean to us this morning.
DOCTOR: Really?
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Why?
FAMILY MEMBER: They told us…
DOCTOR: What did they tell you?

FAMILY MEMBER: They told us that we could not be seen unless we paid them some money. They said J___ had to go home. And I told them how much does he owe? They said one hundred and ninety six dollars. I said well, I was prepared to pay anything-
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: -rather than him go home, but they were so mean. Not the people in the blood draw,
DOCTOR: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: but somebody from the front office. Well if he doesn’t give us ninety six dollars today, he has to go home. We can’t see him. We can’t give him anymore treatment. We called him and told him that. The point is J____ doesn’t remember every phone call. He doesn’t even remember when I call sometimes. But the point is this, I had two hundred dollars in my pocket
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: but I was so mad by that time I wasn’t going to give it to them. I actually had about four hundred in my pocket.
DOCTOR: Chuckles
DOCTOR: Okay.

FAMILY MEMBER: But I’m not giving them nothing. J____ said don’t give them nothing. I said we have to give them something. So I told them I tell you what, I’ll meet you halfway, I’ll give you fifty dollars. And then I went over there and I took a hundred dollar bill and they were looking they were a little pissed some more too because I was waiting for my change back.
DOCTOR: Yes.
FAMILY MEMBER: I said I need a receipt and my change. But they were not friendly about that money and I told them I’d become so, I was not me,
DOCTOR: Sorry.
FAMILY MEMBER: I said I’ve become so disillusioned because this is one of the most inviting, the most warmest-
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: -atmosphere, but I said the whole picture changes
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: and you guys are making it about money and so now we feel less than.
DOCTOR: Uh huh.

FAMILY MEMBER: We feel that you don’t really care about us. It’s our money that you care about. And the lady was looking at me…  I wasn’t fussing either, I was just telling her put yourself in our shoes and then J___ sitting here crazy because he knows-
DOCTOR: xxx
FAMILY MEMBER: - the money that’s worked for in our house I work for. But what he doesn’t understand it’s still ours.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But he has a sense as a man don’t give them your money. It’s our money. But I just thought they were just a little bit less than professional today.
DOCTOR: Right, I agree.
FAMILY MEMBER: Not good. It made him so sad.
DOCTOR: I’m so sorry.
FAMILY MEMBER: He has tears in his eyes because he wants to be the man. And God is the man. He puts whoever in the position has to do whatever they have to do.
DOCTOR: Yeah
FAMILY MEMBER: But the fact is we’re able to do it. It doesn’t matter which pocket it comes.
PATIENT: Well I wasn’t out there. So I’m glad I wasn’t out there.
PATIENT: DOC
PATIENT: Chuckles
PATIENT: I would have said some words. You know.
FAMILY MEMBER: xxx
DOCTOR: Well that was not appropriate.

FAMILY MEMBER: And the point is in situations like that you can’t join a group, you can’t join a crowd, you have to stand out in a separate entity and say well I’m not gonna stoop to their level but I’m not gonna be stupid either.
FAMILY MEMBER: xxx
DOCTOR: Yeah so if are issues along the way –
FAMILY MEMBER: They gave me this application to fill out.
DOCTOR: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or…
DOCTOR: Yeah, I know.
FAMILY MEMBER: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given -
DOCTOR: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know.
DOCTOR: No, I agree.
FAMILY MEMBER: But what I appreciate right now is that you’re listening to us.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because even outside of his care, you want to be treated humanely.
DOCTOR: Absolutely.
FAMILY MEMBER: Or we’ll stay at home and he needs this place.
DOCTOR: I would agree. Who doesn’t need a roof over the heads first of all?
FAMILY MEMBER: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here.
DOCTOR: Well thank you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Seriously.
DOCTOR: laughs
DOCTOR: okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because you care, that she listens.
DOCTOR: But and I have also have some donor money
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If you know, for medical expenses
FAMILY MEMBER: Mm Hmm.
DOCTOR: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: Alright
FAMILY MEMBER: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.
DOCTOR: Of course.
FAMILY MEMBER: Because J___ listens to you.
DOCTOR: Yeah and he’s doing much better too.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes, he is.
DOCTOR: So the cancer meds do you have enough or are you gonna need a refill.

DOCTOR: Okay.

DOCTOR: mumbling
DOCTOR: next time…

DOCTOR: . Okay. So feeling okay?  Nothing changed?

FAMILY MEMBER: Good.

DOCTOR: Now, does it uh cause you any problems, though?  The Norco doesn’t constipate you?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: Does it help with the pain?
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up.

DOCTOR: From four to nine.

DOCTOR: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: No?
DOCTOR: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah. Okay.
DOCTOR: That will continue.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.

DOCTOR: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that.
FAMILY MEMBER: More visits?
DOCTOR: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that.
FAMILY MEMBER: So, like every other week or something like that?

DOCTOR: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way-
PATIENT: Radiation?
DOCTOR: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: So the thing is, Dr. V___, -
DOCTOR: Um, hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.
DOCTOR: Um, hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: We’re spiritual.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: Uh, I just picked up a full-time schedule.
DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Will he need to have somebody come with him?
DOCTOR: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made?
FAMILY MEMBER: He drives.
DOCTOR: Oh, okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere.
DOCTOR: Laughs
DOCTOR: . Okay. So then usually what I tell people-
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do –
FAMILY MEMBER: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new-
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah. Right.
DOCTOR: I would-
FAMILY MEMBER: You want somebody here.
DOCTOR: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: You know?  Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that.
DOCTOR: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.

DOCTOR: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher –
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: - I need to know about it right away.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that-
FAMILY MEMBER: Uh, huh.
DOCTOR: are possible side effects of these medications.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit-
FAMILY MEMBER: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse.
DOCTOR: I know.
FAMILY MEMBER: I’m going to keep my eye on-
DOCTOR: FAM &  talking at the same time
DOCTOR: That’s what I was just going to tell you that I’m going to have to lean on you a little bit more.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes. Yes.
DOCTOR: Because you have the training already.
FAMILY MEMBER: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay?
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But she said is so vitally important -
DOCTOR: - If she needs to call me –
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: - I would rather you over call than you know totally ignore - –
FAMILY MEMBER: Ignore it.
DOCTOR: - and then you get really sick by the time you show up in here.
PATIENT: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: Okay?  I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. Great.
DOCTOR: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.

DOCTOR: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.

DOCTOR: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay?
FAMILY MEMBER: So, we don’t have to go through the study?
DOCTOR: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: As long as but I need your okay for that.
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: That’s fine.
DOCTOR: And if I have that, uh, if they say that, yes, we can go ahead, we’ll let you know and we’ll have them come back to do all the consenting and all of that procedure.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If, however, they say, not right now, it’s too much, if it’s a week or two, I’m okay with waiting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: If it’s going to be a month or more, I don’t think then we should wait. We should look into other things.
FAMILY MEMBER: Try something else.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Makes sense?
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: We stand, we stand in agreement with you.
DOCTOR: Okay. But the good news is that you’re feeling well and the bone disease really did not get any worse.

DOCTOR: And, that includes, um, a whole new class of drugs, um. So, BRCA2 is a gene involved in repairing broken DNA. And, they’re very good at repairing it, um, but when you have a mutation, it screws up a bit -- that, and, so, it predisposes you to cancer. What we’ve found is if we give a drug that blocks another DNA repair enzyme. So, now the cancer cells maybe inherit a bad one, and we block one chemically. For some reason, it doesn’t like having two blocked, and the cancer cells die. So, we sometimes see people respond really well to these new drugs that we treating with. The other thing that we think is happening is, um, when you have DNA repair mutation, the cells - the cancer cells can start making abnormal proteins, and those are recognized by the immune system better. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well.
